revision.text:
{{Use Australian English|date=May 2015}} {{featured article}} {{Infobox military unit |unit_name=No. 77 Squadron RAAF |image=[[File:Raaf 77sqn.jpg|120px|alt=Crest of 77 Squadron, Royal Australian Air Force, featuring a lion and the motto "Swift to Destroy"]] |caption=No. 77 Squadron's crest |dates= 1942–current |country=Australia |branch=[[Royal Australian Air Force]] |role=Air-to-air/air-to-surface combat |FEG=[[Air Combat Group RAAF|Air Combat Group]] |command_structure=[[No. 71 Wing RAAF|No. 71 Wing]] (1943)
[[No. 73 Wing RAAF|No. 73 Wing]] (1943–44)
[[No. 81 Wing RAAF|No. 81 Wing]] (1944–48, 1987–current)
[[No. 91 Wing RAAF|No. 91 Wing]] (1950–54)
[[No. 78 Wing RAAF|No. 78 Wing]] (1955–67) |garrison=[[RAAF Base Williamtown]] |aircraft_fighter=[[McDonnell Douglas F/A-18 Hornet|F/A-18 Hornet]] |motto="Swift to Destroy" |battles=World War II * [[South West Pacific theatre of World War II|South West Pacific theatre]] * [[New Guinea campaign]] * [[Borneo campaign (1945)|Borneo campaign]] [[Occupation of Japan]]
[[Korean War]]
[[Malayan Emergency]]
[[Indonesia–Malaysia confrontation]]
[[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|War in Afghanistan]]
[[Military intervention against ISIL]] |decorations=[[Republic of Korea Presidential Unit Citation|Presidential Unit Citation]] (South Korea) |notable_commanders={{nowrap|[[Dick Cresswell]] (1942–43, 1944–45, 1950–51)}}
[[Gordon Steege]] (1951)
[[John Quaife]] (1996–98){{cite web|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/Contents/About-APDC/About-APDC/Office-of-Air-Force-History/Air-Marshals-of-the-RAAF/137/Air-Vice-Marshals-L-Z.aspx |title=Air Vice-Marshals (L–Z) |publisher=Air Power Development Centre |accessdate=18 August 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110601195011/http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/Contents/About-APDC/About-APDC/Office-of-Air-Force-History/Air-Marshals-of-the-RAAF/137/Air-Vice-Marshals-L-Z.aspx |archivedate=1 June 2011 }}
[[Mark Binskin]] (1998–99){{cite web|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/Contents/About-APDC/About-APDC/Office-of-Air-Force-History/Air-Marshals-of-the-RAAF/134/Air-Marshals.aspx |title=Air Marshals |publisher=Air Power Development Centre |accessdate=18 August 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110601193800/http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/Contents/About-APDC/About-APDC/Office-of-Air-Force-History/Air-Marshals-of-the-RAAF/134/Air-Marshals.aspx |archivedate=1 June 2011 }} }} '''No. 77 Squadron''' is a [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF) squadron headquartered at [[RAAF Base Williamtown]], New South Wales. It is controlled by [[No. 81 Wing RAAF|No. 81 Wing]], and equipped with [[McDonnell Douglas F/A-18 Hornet]] multi-role fighters. The squadron was formed at [[RAAF Base Pearce|RAAF Station Pearce]], Western Australia, in March 1942 and saw action in the [[South West Pacific theatre of World War II]], operating [[Curtiss P-40 Warhawk variants|Curtis P-40 Kittyhawks]]. After the war, it re-equipped with [[North American P-51 Mustang]]s and deployed to Japan as part of the [[British Commonwealth Occupation Force]]. The squadron was about to return to Australia when the [[Korean War]] broke out in June 1950, after which it joined [[United Nations]] forces supporting South Korea. It converted from Mustangs to [[Gloster Meteor]] jets between April and July 1951 and remained in Korea until October 1954, claiming five [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-15|MiG-15]]s and over five thousand buildings and vehicles destroyed during the war for the loss of almost sixty aircraft, mainly to ground fire. The squadron re-equipped with [[CAC Sabre]]s at Williamtown in November 1956. Two years later it transferred to [[RMAF Butterworth|RAAF Butterworth]] in [[Federation of Malaya|Malaya]] to join the air campaign against communist guerrillas in the last stages of the [[Malayan Emergency|Emergency]]. The squadron remained at Butterworth during the 1960s, providing regional air defence during the [[Indonesia–Malaysia confrontation|''Konfrontasi'']] between Indonesia and Malaysia. It returned to Williamtown in early 1969 to re-equip with [[Dassault Mirage III]] supersonic jet fighters. No. 77 Squadron began converting to Hornets in June 1987. It supplied a detachment of four aircraft to the American base on [[Diego Garcia]] in 2001–02, supporting the [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|war in Afghanistan]], and deployed to the Middle East as part of the [[military intervention against ISIL]] in 2015–16. Along with its Hornets, the squadron briefly operated [[Pilatus PC-9]]s in the [[forward air control]] role in the early 2000s. The RAAF plans to replace its Hornets with [[Lockheed Martin F-35 Lightning II]] fighters commencing in 2018, and No. 77 Squadron is scheduled to convert to the new type in 2021. ==Role and equipment== [[File:No 77 Sqn RAAF pilots Feb 2010.JPG|thumb|left|upright=1.48|Pilots of No. 77 Squadron in their F/A-18 Hornets, 2010|alt= A row of helmeted pilots in the cockpits of their fighter jets]] No. 77 Squadron is located at [[RAAF Base Williamtown]], New South Wales, and controlled by [[No. 81 Wing RAAF|No. 81 Wing]], which is part of [[Air Combat Group RAAF|Air Combat Group]].{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/About-us/Structure-of-the-RAAF/Air-Command/Air-Combat-Group/No.-81-Wing-/No.-77-Squadron/?RAAF-swngGZzQiBV3JZSvniJewKj9fDOFiixX|title=No. 77 Squadron|publisher=[[Royal Australian Air Force]]|accessdate=22 August 2014}} No. 81 Wing maintains three fighter squadrons for [[Offensive counter air|offensive and defensive counter-air]] operations.{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/About_us/Structure_of_the_RAAF/Air_Command/Air_Combat_Group/No._81_Wing_/?RAAF-UInnSuKVCZ/AuQLnytaHcdNP6c14SIt0|title= No. 81 Wing|publisher= Royal Australian Air Force|accessdate=22 August 2014}} As well as air-to-air combat, No. 77 Squadron is tasked with land strike, [[close air support]] and maritime strike missions. Its staff includes maintenance, supply and other support personnel. The unit motto is "Swift to Destroy" and the crest features an [[Chinese guardian lions|oriental temple lion]], a legacy of No. 77 Squadron's role in the [[Korean War]]. Nicknamed the "grumpy monkey", the lion represents "a defender of peace, which, when disturbed, is swift to destroy".{{cite hansard |jurisdiction=New South Wales |url=https://www.parliament.nsw.gov.au/Hansard/Pages/HansardResult.aspx#/docid/HANSARD-1323879322-83629 |house=[[New South Wales Legislative Assembly|Legislative Assembly]] |date=3 June 2004 |title=Royal Australian Air Force 77 Squadron| page=9623 |speaker=[[Peta Seaton]] |position=[[Electoral district of Southern Highlands|Member for Southern Highlands]]|accessdate=28 May 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/raafmuseum/research/units/77sqn.htm |title= No. 77 Squadron|publisher= [[RAAF Museum]]|accessdate=22 August 2014}} The squadron operates [[McDonnell Douglas F/A-18 Hornet]] multi-role fighters, the first of which was delivered in June 1987. The twin-engined Hornet is armed with a [[20 mm caliber|20 mm cannon]] and can carry short- and medium-range air-to-air missiles and a variety of guided and unguided air-to-surface ordnance.{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/raafmuseum/research/aircraft/series3/A21.htm |title= F/A-18 Hornet|publisher= RAAF Museum|accessdate=22 August 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/About-us/Structure-of-the-RAAF/Air-Command/Air-Combat-Group/No.-81-Wing-/No.-77-Squadron/?RAAF-swngGZzQiBV3JZSvniJewKj9fDOFiixX|title=No. 77 Squadron aircraft|publisher=Royal Australian Air Force|accessdate=22 August 2014}} It can be [[aerial refueling|refuelled in flight]] by the RAAF's [[Airbus A330 MRTT|Airbus KC-30A Multi Role Tanker Transports]].{{cite magazine|title=RAAF takes delivery of final KC-30|url=http://australianaviation.com.au/2012/12/raaf-takes-delivery-of-final-kc-30/|accessdate=22 August 2014|magazine=[[Australian Aviation (magazine)|Australian Aviation]]|date=4 December 2012}} No. 77 Squadron primarily operates the single-seat F/A-18A Hornet; each Hornet squadron also operates one or two F/A-18Bs, a two-seat model used for pilot conversion. Squadron staff are responsible for day-to-day servicing and some heavy maintenance tasks. Other heavy maintenance is carried out by an industry coalition contracted through [[Boeing Australia|Boeing]].ANAO, ''Management of Air Combat Fleet In-Service Support'', p. 54 No. 77 Squadron regularly undertakes exercises with air forces from South-East Asia, New Zealand and the United States.{{cite magazine |url=http://www.defence.gov.au/news/raafnews/editions/5414/5414.pdf|last=Friend|first=Cath|last2=Hamilton|first2=Eamon |title=Welcome to Pitch Black|magazine=[[Air Force (newspaper)|Air Force]]|date=2 August 2012|page=5|accessdate=24 August 2014}} ==History== ===World War II=== [[File:77 Sqn RAAF pilots & Kittyhawk (AWM NWA0019).JPG|thumb|upright=1.38|right|Pilots of B Flight, No. 77 Squadron, including [[Flying Officer]] John Gorton (back row, fourth from left) with a {{nowrap|P-40 Kittyhawk}} in the Northern Territory, January 1943|alt=Three rows of men light-coloured military uniforms, in front of the single-engined aircraft]] As the Japanese advanced in the South West Pacific during early 1942, the RAAF hurriedly established three fighter units—[[No. 75 Squadron RAAF|Nos. 75]], [[No. 76 Squadron RAAF|76]] and 77 Squadrons—equipped with [[Curtiss P-40 Warhawk variants|Curtiss P-40E Kittyhawks]] recently delivered from the United States.Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 139–141 No. 77 Squadron was formed at [[RAAF Base Pearce|RAAF Station Pearce]], Western Australia, on 16 March, with a complement of three officers and 100 men. Temporarily commanded by [[Squadron Leader]] D. F. Forsyth, the unit was initially responsible for the defence of [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]].RAAF Historical Section, ''Fighter Units'', pp. 54–56No. 77 Squadron (1942–50), "Operations Record Book", p. 1 Squadron Leader [[Dick Cresswell]] assumed command on 20 April.RAAF Historical Section, ''Fighter Units'', pp. 60–61 The squadron transferred to [[Batchelor Airfield]] near [[Darwin, Northern Territory|Darwin]], Northern Territory, in August, the first RAAF fighter unit to be stationed in the area.Eather, ''Flying Squadrons of the Australian Defence Force'', pp. 89–91 Until this time, air defence over Darwin had been provided by the P-40s flown by the [[United States Army Air Forces|USAAF]]'s [[49th Operations Group|49th Fighter Group]].Johnston, ''Whispering Death'', pp. 136, 249 No. 77 Squadron moved to another of Darwin's satellite airfields, [[Livingstone Airfield|Livingstone]], in September.Gillison, [https://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070521--1-.pdf ''Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 644] Among its pilots was [[John Gorton]], future [[Prime Minister of Australia]].Johnston, ''Whispering Death'', p. 250 No. 77 Squadron saw action defending Darwin from Japanese air raids and claimed its first aerial victory just after 5 a.m. on 23 November 1942, when Cresswell destroyed a [[Mitsubishi G4M|Mitsubishi "Betty"]] bomber.Johnston, ''Whispering Death'', pp. 250–251 It was the first "kill" for an Australian squadron over the mainland, and the first night victory over Australia. As of 24 December, the unit's strength was twenty-four Kittyhawks.Gillison, [http://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070521--1-.pdf ''Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 649] In February 1943, concurrent with [[No. 1 Wing RAAF|No. 1 Wing]] and its three [[Supermarine Spitfire]] squadrons becoming operational in the Darwin area, No. 77 Squadron was transferred to [[Milne Bay]] in New Guinea.Gillison, [http://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070521--1-.pdf ''Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 651]Johnston, ''Whispering Death'', pp. 267, 291 Along with [[No. 6 Squadron RAAF|Nos. 6]], 75 and [[No. 100 Squadron RAAF|100 Squadrons]] it came under the control of the newly formed [[No. 71 Wing RAAF|No. 71 Wing]], which was part of [[No. 9 Operational Group RAAF|No. 9 Operational Group]], the RAAF's main mobile formation in the [[South West Pacific theatre of World War II|South West Pacific Area]].Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070531--1-.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 23–24]Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 144 No. 77 Squadron registered its first daytime victory on 11 April, when a Kittyhawk shot down a [[Mitsubishi A6M Zero|Mitsubishi Zero]] taking part in a raid on Allied shipping near [[Buna, Papua New Guinea|Buna]]. Three days later the Japanese attacked Milne Bay; the squadron claimed four bombers and a fighter for the loss of one Kittyhawk.Johnston, ''Whispering Death'', pp. 285–287 By this time, Allied headquarters had finalised plans for a drive north to the Philippines involving heavy attacks on [[Rabaul]] and the occupation of territory in New Guinea, [[New Britain]] and the Solomon Islands.Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070531--1-.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 21–22] [[File:No. 77 Squadron Kittyhawk 1943 (AWM P01370.011).JPG|thumb|upright=1.28|left|No. 77 Squadron P-40 Kittyhawks at Milne Bay, 1943|alt=Two single-engined military aircraft parked in front of palm trees]] No. 77 Squadron began moving to [[Goodenough Island]] in May 1943, and was fully established and ready for operations by 15 June.Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070531--1-.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 33–36] As Japanese fighter opposition was limited, the squadron took part in several ground-attack missions in New Britain, armed with [[Incendiary device|incendiary]] and general-purpose bombs, a practice that had been employed by Kittyhawk units in the [[Mediterranean and Middle East theatre of World War II|Middle East]].Johnston, ''Whispering Death'', p. 320 During one such raid on 2 August, Cresswell's designated successor as commanding officer, [[Flight Lieutenant]] Daryl Sproule, was forced to crash-land on a beach and was captured and executed by the Japanese.Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070554--1-.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', p. 71] Cresswell remained in command until Squadron Leader "Buster" Brown took over on 20 August. Japanese fighter strength in New Britain and New Guinea increased in September and October, and eight of No. 77 Squadron's Kittyhawks were briefly detached to [[Nadzab]] as escorts for the [[CAC Boomerang]]s of [[No. 4 Squadron RAAF|No. 4 Squadron]], which were supporting the [[7th Division (Australia)|7th Australian Division]].Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070554--1-.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 80, 86] In January 1944, No. 77 Squadron took part in the two largest raids mounted by the RAAF to that time, each involving over seventy aircraft attacking targets in New Britain.Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070557--1-.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 130–131] It was subsequently assigned to [[Los Negros Island|Los Negros]] in the [[Admiralty Islands]], under the control of [[No. 73 Wing RAAF|No. 73 Wing]], along with Nos. 76 and [[No. 79 Squadron RAAF|79 Squadrons]].Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070560--1-.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', p. 170] No. 77 Squadron's ground party went ashore at Los Negros on 6 March, in the middle of a firefight with Japanese forces.Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070560--1-.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', p. 173] Fourteen of the squadron's Kittyhawks arrived a week later, and another ten on 28 March.Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070560--1-.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 176, 179] Their primary duty was providing air cover for Allied shipping, though no Japanese aircraft were encountered; they also flew ground-attack missions in support of US troops on [[Manus Island]].Johnston, ''Whispering Death'', p. 340 Following the capture of the Admiralties, which completed the isolation of Rabaul, No. 77 Squadron remained with No. 73 Wing on garrison duty at Los Negros from May to July 1944.Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070560--1-.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 180–181]Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070730--1-.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', p. 249] Between 13 August and 14 September 1944, the squadron transferred to [[Noemfoor]] in western New Guinea to join Nos. 76 and [[No. 82 Squadron RAAF|82 Squadrons]] as part of [[No. 81 Wing RAAF|No. 81 Wing]] under No. 10 Operational Group (later the [[Australian First Tactical Air Force]]), which had taken over the mobile role previously performed by No. 9 Group and was supporting the American landings along the north coast of New Guinea. Cresswell, now a [[Wing commander (rank)|wing commander]], arrived for his second tour of duty as commanding officer on 26 September. Operating P-40N Kittyhawks, No. 77 Squadron bombed Japanese positions on the [[Vogelkop Peninsula]] in October and on [[Halmahera]] in November.Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070566--1-.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', p. 312] Cresswell handed over command in March 1945.{{cite web|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/HistoryRecord/HistoryRecordDetail.aspx?rid=340|title=Cresswell led 77 Squadron for third time|publisher=Air Power Development Centre|accessdate=20 December 2014}} The squadron moved to [[Morotai]] on 13 April and conducted ground-attack [[sortie]]s over the [[Dutch East Indies]] until 30 June, when it redeployed with No. 81 Wing to [[Crown Colony of Labuan|Labuan]] to support the [[9th Division (Australia)|9th Australian Division]] in [[North Borneo]] until hostilities ended in August 1945.Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070402--1-.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 470–473] The squadron's tally of aerial victories during the war was seven aircraft destroyed and four "probables", for the loss of eighteen pilots killed.Johnston, ''Whispering Death'', p. 448 ===Occupation of Japan=== [[File:F-51Ds 77 Sqn RAAF at Iwakuni c1950.jpg|thumb|upright=1.38|right|No. 77 Squadron P-51 Mustang fighters undergoing maintenance at Iwakuni, Japan, c. 1950|alt=Three single-seat military monoplanes, two with engines exposed, parked on tarmac with huts and mountains in the background]] No. 77 Squadron began re-equipping with [[North American P-51 Mustang]]s at Labuan in September 1945.Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070415--1-.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 495–496] In the wake of Japan's surrender, No. 81 Wing became part of Australia's contribution to the [[British Commonwealth Occupation Force]] (BCOF). No. 77 Squadron was the last of the wing's three flying units to deploy to Japan, arriving at [[Hōfu, Yamaguchi|Bofu]], a former [[kamikaze]] base, on 21 March 1946.Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 213–216 No. 481 (Maintenance) Squadron provided technical service for the Mustangs.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', p. 214 Occupation duties proved uneventful, the main operational task being surveillance patrols, but units maintained an intensive training regime and undertook combined exercises with other Allied forces.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 216–218 Many RAAF personnel were accompanied to Japan by their families.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', p. 220 No. 81 Wing transferred to [[Iwakuni, Yamaguchi|Iwakuni]] in April 1948, the same month that the Federal government decided to reduce Australia's contribution to BCOF, retaining only No. 77 Squadron in Japan.{{cite web|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/HistoryRecord/HistoryRecordDetail.aspx?rid=176 |title=Occupation air group arrived in Japan|publisher= Air Power Development Centre|accessdate= 29 March 2013}} Wing headquarters and No. 481 Squadron disbanded in November 1948, and No. 77 Squadron came under the aegis of a new organisation called RAAF Component.{{cite web|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/HistoryRecord/HistoryRecordDetail.aspx?rid=129|title= RAAF garrison in Japan downgraded|publisher=Air Power Development Centre|accessdate=6 April 2013}} The squadron was now the largest operational unit in the RAAF, with a strength of 299 officers and men, forty Mustangs, three [[CAC Wirraway]]s, two [[Douglas C-47 Skytrain|Douglas C-47 Dakotas]] and two [[Auster]]s.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', p. 222 The Dakotas and Austers formed the No. 77 Squadron Communications Flight.Wilson, ''The Brotherhood of Airmen'', p. 170Hurst, ''The Forgotten Few'', p. 29 In December 1949, the Mustangs competed in a gunnery competition against three groups of Mustangs and two groups of [[Lockheed P-80 Shooting Star|F-80 Shooting Star]] jets belonging to the US [[Far East Air Force (United States)|Far East Air Force]] (FEAF). No. 77 Squadron's Flight Lieutenant "Bay" Adams achieved the highest individual score of the competition, earning the personal congratulations of Lieutenant Generals [[George E. Stratemeyer]], commander of FEAF, and [[Horace Robertson]], commander of BCOF.Eather, ''Odd Jobs'', pp. 17–18 The RAAF personnel were preparing to return to Australia when, on 25 June 1950, they were placed on standby for action in the [[Korean War]], which had just broken out.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 222–224 ===Korean War=== [[File:Lou Spence of 77 Sqn RAAF (AWM JK1019).JPG|thumb|right|upright=1.38|Wing Commander Lou Spence, commanding No. 77 Squadron, prior to a mission over Korea, August 1950|alt=Man in flying suit in the cockpit of a single-seat fighter]] Led by Wing Commander Lou Spence, No. 77 Squadron was committed to action over Korea as part of [[United Nations Command]], and came under the operational control of the US [[Fifth Air Force]].Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 229–230 The Australian unit was specifically requested by General [[Douglas MacArthur]], commander of UN forces; the Mustang was considered the best long-range ground-attack aircraft in the theatre, and Stratemeyer contended that No. 77 Squadron was the best Mustang outfit in Japan.O'Neill, ''Australia in the Korean War: Volume 1'', pp. 52–53 The squadron flew its initial escort and patrol sorties from Iwakuni on 2 July 1950, becoming the first non-American UN unit to commence operations.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', p. 225 Several Australian families were still living at Iwakuni pending their repatriation from what had become an operational theatre, and could watch the Mustangs depart for missions over Korea.Hurst, ''The Forgotten Few'', pp. 32–33 A [[friendly fire]] incident occurred on 3 July 1950, when No. 77 Squadron attacked a train full of US and South Korean troops on the main highway between [[Suwon]] and [[Pyongtaek|P'yongtaek]], inflicting many casualties, twenty-nine of them fatal.O'Neill, ''Australia in the Korean War: Volume 2'', p. 305Eather, ''Odd Jobs'', p. 86 Spence had raised concerns before the mission that the North Koreans could not have penetrated so far south, but was assured by Fifth Air Force controllers that the target was correct; the incident was widely reported in US newspapers but a public statement by Stratemeyer cleared the RAAF of any blame.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', p. 226Hurst, ''The Forgotten Few'', p. 35 No. 77 Squadron did not encounter enemy aircraft in the opening phase of the war but often faced intense ground fire. It suffered its first fatality on 7 July when its deputy commander, Squadron Leader Graham Strout, was killed during a raid on [[Samcheok|Samchok]]. He was also the first Australian, and the first non-American UN serviceman, to die in Korea.Hurst, ''The Forgotten Few'', p. 39Eather, ''Odd Jobs'', p. xvii For the next two months, equipped with bombs, rockets and [[napalm]], No. 77 Squadron supported UN troops retreating before the North Korean advance. To expedite turnaround times between missions, the Mustangs, which were still based at Iwakuni, often refuelled and rearmed at [[Daegu|Taegu]] near the [[Battle of Pusan Perimeter|Pusan Perimeter]], where UN forces made a last-ditch stand on the southern tip of Korea.Eather, ''Odd Jobs'', pp. 92–94 One of the squadron's Dakotas regularly flew between Iwakuni and Taegu carrying ordnance and spare parts. According to the official history of the Air Force in 1946–71, the squadron's part in the victory at Pusan earned recognition "not only for the RAAF but also Australia at the highest political levels in the United States". During a visit to Japan in August 1950, Prime Minister [[Robert Menzies]] presented the [[Gloucester Cup]] to No. 77 Squadron as the RAAF's most proficient unit of the past year.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article135299764 |title=Persistency on Korea failed |newspaper=[[The Newcastle Herald|Newcastle Morning Herald and Miners' Advocate]] |date=16 August 1950 |accessdate=5 September 2014 |page=3 }} That month, the squadron claimed thirty-five tanks, 212 other vehicles, eighteen railway engines or cars, and thirteen fuel or ammunition dumps destroyed.Hurst, ''The Forgotten Few'', p. 55 [[File:No. 77 Sqn RAAF in Korea (AWM JK0024) (cropped).JPG|thumb|left|upright=1.38|Squadron Leader Dick Cresswell (centre), on his third tour commanding No. 77 Squadron, briefs Meteor pilots at Kimpo prior to a mission over North Korea, August 1951|alt=Twelve men in flying suits in a semi-circle around another man in front of a twin-engined jet aircraft]] On 3 September 1950, [[Sergeant]] Bill Harrop was forced down behind enemy lines and executed by the North Koreans.Eather, ''Odd Jobs'', pp. 95–96Hurst, ''The Forgotten Few'', p. 59 Six days later, Spence was killed when his Mustang failed to pull out of a dive during a napalm attack on [[Angang-eup|Angang-ni]].Stephens, ''Going Solo'', p. 227Hurst, ''The Forgotten Few'', p. 61 His death was a serious blow to the squadron, and the RAAF despatched Cresswell on his third tour as commanding officer to replace him. Cresswell arrived at Iwakuni on 17 September and set about restoring morale, undertaking four sorties on his first day of operations three days later.Hurst, ''The Forgotten Few'', pp. 62–64 MacArthur had meanwhile launched an [[Battle of Inchon|amphibious landing]] behind North Korean lines at [[Incheon|Inchon]], forcing the communists to retreat from the Pusan Perimeter. No. 77 Squadron was transferred from Iwakuni to [[Pohang]], South Korea, on 12 October, to support UN forces advancing northwards.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 227–228 On 20 October, the squadron became a component of the RAAF's newly established [[No. 91 Wing RAAF|No. 91 (Composite) Wing]], which also included [[No. 391 Squadron RAAF|No. 391 (Base) Squadron]], [[No. 491 Squadron RAAF|No. 491 (Maintenance) Squadron]], and [[No. 30 Transport Unit RAAF|No. 30 Communications Flight]], formerly the No. 77 Squadron Communications Flight.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', p. 228 The wing and all units except No. 77 Squadron, which came under the operational control of the US [[35th Fighter-Interceptor Group]], were headquartered at Iwakuni. China entered the war in mid-October 1950, as advancing UN troops closed in on the [[Yalu River]]. No. 77 Squadron undertook its first sorties against Chinese ground forces on 1 November.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', p. 229 The squadron flew its first missions supporting the [[Australian Army]] on 5 November, when it attacked Chinese troops opposing the [[3rd Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment]], at [[Pakchon County|Pakchon]].Eather, ''Odd Jobs'', p. 102Hurst, ''The Forgotten Few'', p. 84 No. 77 Squadron personnel were housed in tents in freezing conditions at Pohung; two pilots died from burns after a fire in their quarters on 14 November.Eather, ''Odd Jobs'', pp. 100–101 Two days later the Australians began moving forward with the 35th Group to Yonpo, near [[Hamhung]].Hurst, ''The Forgotten Few'', p. 80 North Korea's counter-attack, supported by Chinese forces, led to the squadron being withdrawn to [[Pusan]] on 3 December 1950.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', p. 231 The communists operated a Russian-designed swept-wing jet fighter, the [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-15]], that was far superior to all other fighters in the theatre except the new [[North American F-86 Sabre]].Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 229–230 Although the MiGs carried Chinese or North Korean markings, they were frequently operated by seasoned [[Soviet Air Forces|Russian air force]] pilots, whose deployment was unofficial, as the [[Soviet Union]] was not a combatant in the Korean War.Krylov; Tepsurkaev, ''Soviet MiG-15 Aces of the Korean War'', pp. 40, 51Hurst, ''The Forgotten Few'', pp. 107, 140 [[File:No. 77 Sqn RAAF Meteor in Korea (AWM JK0072).JPG|thumb|right|upright=1.38|No. 77 Squadron Meteor at Kimpo preparing for a bomber escort mission over North Korea, 1951|alt=Twin-jet military aircraft parked at airfield]] The RAAF attempted to procure Sabres to replace No. 77 Squadron's Mustangs but the priority being given to re-equipping the USAF meant that deliveries would not be possible until 1954. The Australian government agreed to purchase [[Gloster Meteor]] straight-wing jet fighters from Britain as the only viable alternative; the initial order included thirty-six single-seat Mk.8 interceptors and four two-seat Mk.7 trainers. No. 77 Squadron completed its last Mustang mission on 6 April 1951 and returned to Iwakuni the next day to begin converting to Meteors. It subsequently transferred to [[Gimpo|Kimpo]], South Korea, and commenced operations with its new aircraft on 29 July.Eather, ''Odd Jobs'', pp. 119, 126Hurst, ''The Forgotten Few'', pp. 126, 142 The squadron deployed twenty-two Meteors at Kimpo, and came under the control of the USAF's [[4th Fighter Wing|4th Fighter-Interceptor Wing]]. Although it had operated effectively as a ground-attack unit with its Mustangs, No. 77 Squadron's primary role in the RAAF was interception, and it was expected that with the Meteor it could again focus on fighter duties, particularly as by this stage the USAF had only two squadrons of Sabres in the theatre.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 231–233 Wing Commander [[Gordon Steege]] succeeded Cresswell on 16 August 1951, by which time No. 77 Squadron's Meteors had conducted offensive sweeps up the Yalu River with USAF Sabres, and escorted [[Boeing B-29 Superfortress]]es on bombing missions.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', p. 234Hurst, ''The Forgotten Few'', pp. 143–145 MiG-15s had appeared on several occasions without engaging the Meteors; it was speculated at the time, and subsequently confirmed, that they had been observing the performance of the newly arrived RAAF jets.Eather, ''Odd Jobs'', pp. 126–127 No. 77 Squadron's first Meteor fatalities occurred on 22 August, when two aircraft collided in mid-air as they returned to Kimpo after a sweep.RAAF Historical Section, ''Fighter Units'', p. 58 The Meteors first engaged MiG-15s on 25 August, but scored no hits. Four days later, eight Meteors and sixteen Sabres fought twelve MiGs; one RAAF pilot ejected when his aircraft was shot down, and a second Meteor was badly damaged. One week later another Meteor suffered severe damage in a dogfight with MiGs.Hurst, ''The Forgotten Few'', pp. 147–151 As a result of these clashes, Steege became convinced that the Meteor was outclassed as a fighter. Following discussions with the Fifth Air Force, he decided to take No. 77 Squadron out of its air-to-air combat role and curtail its operations in "[[MiG Alley]]", the area between the Yalu and [[Chongchon River]]s on North Korea's border with [[Manchuria]]. This caused controversy among those who believed that proper tactics exploiting the Meteor's manoeuvrability and heavy armament would have allowed it to remain competitive as a fighter; for the Australian pilots the change of role amounted to a loss of prestige.Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 236–237O'Neill, ''Australia in the Korean War: Volume 2'', pp. 335, 358 The [[Chief of Air Force (Australia)|Chief of the Air Staff]], Air Marshal [[George Jones (RAAF officer)|George Jones]], backed the decision, which relegated the squadron mainly to escort duty and local air defence. Morale suffered and it was not until Wing Commander Ron Susans succeeded Steege on 26 December 1951 that the Meteors were once more assigned an offensive role, namely ground attack.Wilson, ''The Brotherhood of Airmen'', pp. 181–182 [[File:77 Sqn (AWM JK1025).jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.18|No. 77 Squadron pilots and their Meteors at Kunsan, South Korea, June 1954. The nose section of aircraft A77-368 later went on display at the [[Australian War Memorial]], Canberra.{{cite web|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/visit/post-1945-galleries/meteor/|title=Nose of Meteor jet fighter|publisher=[[Australian War Memorial]]|accessdate=28 November 2014}}|alt=Three men in flying suits walking among twin-jet military aircraft]] In the intervening period, Flight Lieutenant "Smoky" Dawson registered No. 77 Squadron's first jet combat claim when he damaged a MiG during an escort mission near [[Anju, South Pyongan|Anju]], North Korea, on 26 September 1951.Eather, ''Odd Jobs'', pp. 132–133 On 27 October, Flying Officer Les Reading was credited with damaging another MiG while covering B-29s over [[Sinanju]]; it was subsequently confirmed as having been destroyed, making it the squadron's first MiG "kill".Eather, ''Odd Jobs'', p. 136Hurst, ''The Forgotten Few'', p. 152 The squadron was awarded the [[Republic of Korea Presidential Unit Citation]] for "exceptionally meritorious service & heroism" on 1 November.{{cite web|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/items/ACCNUM_LARGE/RCDIG1068965/RCDIG1068965--827-.JPG|title=Recommendation: Republic of Korea Presidential Unit Citation|publisher=Australian War Memorial|accessdate=8 September 2014}}Hurst, ''The Forgotten Few'', p. 167 On 1 December 1951, [[Battle of Sunchon (air)|over Sunchon]], at least twenty Soviet-piloted MiGs from the [[176th Guards Fighter Air Regiment]] (''176 GvIAP'') attacked a formation of fourteen Meteors. Both sides apparently overestimated the scale of the battle and the damage inflicted to their opponents: while three Meteors were lost, Soviet pilots claimed nine Meteors destroyed; Australian pilots claimed one MiG shot down and another damaged, from a formation of at least forty MiGs, while Russian sources suggest that all of the MiGs returned to base and less than 25 MiGs were available to ''176 GvIAP'' at the time.Hurst, ''The Forgotten Few'', pp. 171–172Krylov; Tepsurkaev, ''Soviet MiG-15 Aces of the Korean War'', pp. 48–49 On 8 January 1952, Susans led the squadron on its first ground-attack mission in Meteors, which were armed with eight rockets under the wings as well as their four internal 20 mm cannon, at [[Chongdan County|Chongdan]].Stephens, ''Going Solo'', p. 238Hurst, ''The Forgotten Few'', p. 182 They continued to operate mainly in the ground-attack role until the end of the war, but registered two more victories over MiGs near [[Pyongyang]] on 4 and 8 May 1952.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', p. 241Hurst, ''The Forgotten Few'', pp. 194–195 The squadron took part in a mass air strike on 29 August, when 420 UN aircraft attacked Pyongyang.Eather, ''Odd Jobs'', pp. 150–151Hurst, ''The Forgotten Few'', pp. 201–202 One Meteor was shot down and another damaged by MiGs following a ground-attack mission on 2 October 1952.Eather, ''Odd Jobs'', p. 152 The squadron played a leading role in the destruction of a large North Korean convoy on 16 March 1953: two Meteors discovered a line of some 140 vehicles in a mountain pass south of [[Wonsan]], halted it by destroying trucks at the front and rear of the convoy, and then called in further support from Kimpo and the USAF. The Australian aircraft eventually claimed twenty-four trucks out of a total of ninety vehicles destroyed or damaged by UN forces.{{cite web|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/HistoryRecord/HistoryRecordDetail.aspx?rid=306|title=Communist road convoy destroyed in Korea|publisher=Air Power Development centre|accessdate=20 August 2016}}Hurst, ''The Forgotten Few'', p. 214–215 No. 77 Squadron was credited with downing its last MiG southeast of Pyongyang on 27 March.Hurst, ''The Forgotten Few'', pp. 215–216 Squadron Leader Len McGlinchey became its final wartime fatality when his Meteor crashed while taking off from Kimpo on 16 July.Hurst, ''The Forgotten Few'', p. 223 Following the armistice on 27 July 1953, the squadron remained in South Korea on garrison duties—initially at Kimpo, later at [[Gunsan|Kunsan]]—until transferring to Iwakuni on 12 October 1954.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', p. 242 It departed for Australia on 19 November and arrived in [[Sydney]] on 3 December, having been based overseas for eleven years, a record for an RAAF unit.{{cite web|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/HistoryRecord/HistoryRecordDetail.aspx?rid=74|title=77 Squadron home after 11 years away|publisher=Air Power Development Centre|accessdate=30 November 2014}} Its performance in the early days of the war has been cited as a factor in the United States' decision to ratify the [[ANZUS]] treaty in September 1951.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 35–36 The squadron's casualty rate in Korea was twenty-five percent killed or captured.Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 240Eather, ''Odd Jobs'', p. 162 Forty-one pilots died, thirty-five from the RAAF and six on exchange from the [[Royal Air Force]].Hurst, ''The Forgotten Few'', p. 207 A further seven pilots became prisoners of war.RAAF Historical Section, ''Fighter Units'', p. 59Hurst, ''The Forgotten Few'', p. 228 Aircraft losses totalled almost sixty, including over forty Meteors, mostly to ground fire.Hurst, ''The Forgotten Few'', pp. 230–232 The squadron flew 18,872 sorties, including 3,872 in Mustangs and 15,000 in Meteors.Hurst, ''The Forgotten Few'', p. 224 It was credited with shooting down five MiG-15s and destroying 3,700 buildings, 1,408 vehicles, ninety-eight railway engines and carriages, and sixteen bridges.Hurst, ''The Forgotten Few'', p. 231 {{Clear}} ===Malayan Emergency and ''Konfrontasi''=== [[File:Sabre Mk32s RAAF in Thailand early 1960s.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.38|RAAF Sabres in Thailand, c. 1962|alt=Single-engined fighter jet being refuelled from tanker truck]] No. 77 Squadron became operational at [[RAAF Base Williamtown]], New South Wales, on 4 January 1955.O'Neill, ''Australia in the Korean War'', p. 592 On 21 March, it joined [[No. 3 Squadron RAAF|Nos. 3]] and 75 Squadrons as part of [[No. 78 Wing RAAF|No. 78 Wing]], which had recently been reorganised following garrison duty in Malta.No. 78 Wing, "Operations Record Book", pp. 372–373 No. 77 Squadron ceased Meteor operations in August 1956 and re-formed on 19 November equipped with [[CAC Sabre]]s. Between October 1958 and February 1959, Nos. 3 and 77 Squadrons deployed with No. 78 Wing to [[RMAF Butterworth|RAAF Butterworth]] in [[Federation of Malaya|Malaya]], to support Commonwealth forces in the [[Malayan Emergency|Emergency]]. The Sabres were among the first to wear the RAAF's recently introduced "leaping kangaroo" roundel.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 252, 259–260 No. 478 (Maintenance) Squadron provided servicing for the aircraft.RAAF Historical Section, ''Maintenance Units'', pp. 59–62 No. 77 Squadron undertook its first mission dive-bombing communist guerrillas on 13 August 1959, and flew two more ground-attack sorties on 10 June 1960.No. 77 Squadron, "Operations Record Book" (1958–79), pp. 80, 115 The RAAF pilots also sometimes tried to startle the communists by diving their jets through the sound barrier to create [[sonic boom]]s that simulated the sound of artillery fire.Eather, ''Odd Jobs'', p. 76 Two No. 77 Squadron Sabres collided in mid-air on 22 July, but both pilots ejected safely. The Emergency was declared officially over on 31 July 1960. The RAAF squadrons remained at Butterworth as part of Australia's contribution to the [[Far East Strategic Reserve|Commonwealth Strategic Reserve]]. Eight Sabres, along with their pilots and ground crew, were detached from No. 77 Squadron in May 1962 to re-form No. 79 Squadron at [[Ubon Royal Thai Air Force Base|Ubon]], Thailand.Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 254–255No. 77 Squadron, "Operations Record Book" (1958–79), pp. 200–201 The Sabres were flown to Thailand via Singapore to give the appearance that they were not drawn from the Strategic Reserve, thus preserving Malaysia's neutrality. Personnel and equipment from Nos. 3 and 77 Squadrons continued to rotate through No. 79 Squadron on a regular basis.Susans, ''The RAAF Mirage Story'', p. vi The Butterworth-based Sabres, armed with [[AIM-9 Sidewinder|Sidewinder missiles]], were responsible for regional air defence during the [[Indonesia–Malaysia confrontation|''Konfrontasi'']] between Indonesia and Malaysia from July 1963 until August 1966, though no combat took place.Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 251–252 From 26 October until 27 November 1965, a detachment of six Sabres from No. 77 Squadron was based at Labuan to conduct combat patrols over the Indonesian–Malaysian border on Borneo.{{cite web|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/HistoryRecord/HistoryRecordDetail.aspx?rid=505 |title=RAAF Sabres began Borneo patrols|publisher= Air Power Development Centre|accessdate= 18 August 2014}} Following the disbandment of No. 78 Wing in November 1967, No. 77 Squadron became an independently operating unit under the command of Headquarters RAAF Butterworth. ===Supersonic era=== No. 77 Squadron returned to Williamtown in early 1969 to re-equip with [[Dassault Mirage III]] supersonic fighters, undertaking its initial flights on 7 July.Susans, ''The RAAF Mirage Story'', p. 94 The Mirages were charged with interception, high- and low-angle bombing, close air support, and photo reconnaissance; their armament included [[30 mm caliber|30 mm cannon]], Sidewinder missiles and conventional bombs.Susans, ''The RAAF Mirage Story'', pp. 94–99, 151 No. 77 Squadron's prime role was ground attack, although none of the RAAF's Mirages ever saw combat.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', p. 359Susans, ''The RAAF Mirage Story'', pp. 94, 120 No. 481 Squadron was responsible for day-to-day servicing, as well as most heavy maintenance.Susans, ''The RAAF Mirage Story'', pp. 147, 152 No. 77 Squadron suffered its first fatal Mirage accident on 3 April 1973, when an aircraft crashed during a training flight at low altitude. Another pilot was killed when his Mirage hit the water during formation flying at night on 24 June 1976.Susans, ''The RAAF Mirage Story'', p. 156 The squadron began training with [[laser-guided bomb]]s in October 1980.Susans, ''The RAAF Mirage Story'', p. 103 As of March 1984, its aircraft complement was nineteen Mirages.Susans, ''The RAAF Mirage Story'', p. 106 Two pilots died following a mid-air collision at low level on 9 April that year.Susans, ''The RAAF Mirage Story'', p. 157 [[File:MirageIIIs RAAF 1984.JPG|thumb|left|upright=1.38|No. 77 Squadron Mirages, September 1984|alt=Side view of two delta-wing jet fighters in flight]] On 1 January 1985, in preparation for the introduction of the [[McDonnell Douglas F/A-18 Hornet]] to Australian service, No. 77 Squadron took over all Mirages and [[Aermacchi MB-326|Macchi MB-326s]] of [[No. 2 Operational Conversion Unit RAAF|No. 2 Operational Conversion Unit]], assuming responsibility for fighter combat instructor, introductory fighter, and Mirage conversion courses.RAAF Historical Section, ''Training Units'', pp. 62–64Susans, ''The RAAF Mirage Story'', pp. 90, 107 The transfer swelled the squadron's strength to fifty-six aircraft—forty Mirages and sixteen Macchis—and over 500 officers and men, making it the largest operational unit in the RAAF.Wilson, ''Phantom, Hornet and Skyhawk in Australian Service'', p. 116{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=_ftVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=aeMDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5512%2C40413|last=Harrington|first=Tony|title=RAAF starts to phase out Mirages after 21 years|work=[[The Age]]|date=12 January 1987|page=5|accessdate=20 August 2014}} Along with a heavily expanded training program, and its existing Australian Army close support role, No. 77 Squadron's fleet support commitment was increased to take up the slack resulting from the diminution of the [[Royal Australian Navy]]'s fixed-wing capability.Susans, ''The RAAF Mirage Story'', pp. 79, 90–91 Its last fatal accident with the Mirage occurred on 2 May 1986; the aircraft crashed into water during air-to-air gunnery practice.Susans, ''The RAAF Mirage Story'', p. 158 The squadron began phasing out the Mirage in July 1986, and took delivery of its first Hornet on 29 June 1987.Susans, ''The RAAF Mirage Story'', p. 110 It had come under the control of a newly re-formed No. 81 Wing that February.{{cite magazine|title=81WG: then and now|magazine=RAAF News|date=July 1994|page=15}} No. 77 Squadron's last Mirage departed Williamtown on 27 November 1987.Susans, ''The RAAF Mirage Story'', p. 153 Hornet maintenance at Williamtown was the responsibility of No. 481 Wing, which had evolved from No. 481 Squadron.RAAF Historical Section, ''Maintenance Units'', pp. 116–117Odgers, ''Air Force Australia'', p. 192 One of No. 77 Squadron's Hornets crashed near [[Rockhampton]], Queensland, on 19 May 1992, killing the pilot and his passenger, a [[Defence Science and Technology Organisation|defence scientist]].{{cite magazine|url=http://airforcenews.realviewdigital.com/?iid=64253&xml=defencenews_airforce.xml#&startpage=14|last=Stackpool|first=Andrew|magazine=Air Force|title=Tragic loss recalled|date=21 June 2012|page=15|accessdate=14 September 2014}} In September that year, the squadron undertook a proving exercise over [[Halifax Bay]] in [[Far North Queensland]], when four of its Hornets—refuelled in flight on the round trip from Williamtown by a [[Boeing 707]] tanker—became the first jet aircraft in Australia to drop [[aerial mine]]s.Wilson, ''Phantom, Hornet and Skyhawk in Australian Service'', pp. 122–123 No. 481 Wing was reorganised as No. 402 Wing in July 1996; the latter transferred its functions to No. 81 Wing's flying squadrons in July 1998.{{cite magazine|magazine=Air Force News|date=September 1998|title=Bulletin board|page=23}} [[File:A21-49 YMAV 20130227 8642 (13102507125).jpg|thumb|upright=1.38|No. 77 Squadron F/A-18 Hornet in 70th anniversary livery at the [[Australian International Airshow|Avalon Airshow]], [[Avalon Airport|Avalon]], Victoria, 2013|alt=Side view of military combat jet with external fuel tanks and wingtip missiles on a runway]] No. 77 Squadron operated a detachment of [[Pilatus PC-9]] aircraft in the [[forward air control]] role from 2000 until 2003; this role was subsequently filled by the [[Forward Air Control Development Unit RAAF|Forward Air Control Development Unit]]. Four Hornets from No. 77 Squadron were deployed to protect the US base at [[Diego Garcia]] in the [[Indian Ocean]] between November 2001 and February 2002, during the early phase of the [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|war in Afghanistan]].{{cite web|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/HistoryRecord/HistoryRecordDetail.aspx?rid=186 |title=Hornets deployed to Indian Ocean base|publisher= Air Power Development Centre|accessdate= 18 August 2014}} In March 2006, the squadron sent a detachment of aircraft to [[RAAF Base East Sale]], Victoria, to assist with security for the [[2006 Commonwealth Games|Commonwealth Games]] being held in Melbourne.{{cite web|title=RAAF F/A-18s support Commonwealth Games security|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/opacolyte/images/gallery/20060316/index.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141016070009/http://www.defence.gov.au/opacolyte/images/gallery/20060316/index.htm|work=Operation Acolyte|publisher=[[Department of Defence (Australia)|Department of Defence]]|accessdate=30 November 2014|archivedate=16 October 2014}} No. 77 Squadron deployed to the Middle East in September 2015 as part of [[Operation Okra]], Australia's contribution of the [[military intervention against ISIL]]; it handed over to the next rotation, from [[No. 3 Squadron RAAF]], in April 2016.{{cite news|last=Stevenson|first=Chloe|url=http://airforcenews.realviewdigital.com/?iid=136590#folio=4|title=Two say farewell to Tindal|newspaper=Air Force|date=11 February 2016|p=4|accessdate=14 April 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://video.defence.gov.au/play/8wbWJyMjE6Eb1i65MZ1wbGoHsj_8n5MH#|title=77 SQN completes strike rotation in the Middle East|publisher=Department of Defence|work=Defence Videos|date=12 April 2016|accessdate=14 April 2016}} The Australian government plans to replace the Hornet force with seventy-two [[Lockheed Martin F-35 Lightning II]] fighters. Under the [[Defence Materiel Organisation]]'s Project AIR 6000 Phase 2A/B, the first Lightnings will be delivered to the RAAF in late 2018. Each of No. 81 Wing's three fighter squadrons will operate sixteen of the new aircraft. No. 77 Squadron is scheduled to begin conversion in 2021; RAAF Hornet operations are expected to cease the following year.Department of Defence, ''Facilities Requirements for the New Air Combat Capability'', pp. 1–4 ==Battle honours== *World War II: [[Battle of Milne Bay|Milne Bay]], [[Battle of Morotai|Morotai]], [[Borneo campaign (1945)|Borneo 1945]], [[New Guinea campaign|New Guinea 1943–1944]], [[Air raids on Australia, 1942–43|Darwin 1942–1943]], [[Western New Guinea campaign|Dutch New Guinea]], [[New Britain campaign|New Britain 1943]]{{cite web|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/units/unit_11105second_world_war.asp|title=77 Squadron RAAF – Second World War|publisher=Australian War Memorial|accessdate=7 September 2014}} *Korean War: [[Korean War|Korea 1950–1953]]{{cite web|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/units/unit_11105korea.asp|title=77 Squadron RAAF – Korea|publisher=Australian War Memorial|accessdate=7 September 2014}} *Malayan Emergency and ''Konfrontasi'': [[Malayan Emergency|Malaya 1948–1960]], [[Indonesia–Malaysia confrontation|Malaysia (Confrontation) 1962–1966]]{{cite news|last=Stackpool|first=Andrew|author2=Solomou, Bill |title=New battle honours unveiled|url=http://airforcenews.realviewdigital.com/?iid=47220&xml=defencenews_airforce.xml&startpage=4|accessdate=14 September 2014|newspaper=Air Force|date=14 April 2011|pages=4–5}} [[File:No. 77 Squadron Meteors in flight 1952 (AWM JK0242 cropped).jpg|thumb|upright=1.38|No. 77 Squadron Meteors over Iwakuni, Japan, 1952|alt=Three twin-engined, single-seat jet fighters in flight]] ==Aircraft operated== * [[Curtiss P-40 Warhawk variants|Curtiss P-40 Kittyhawk]] (March 1942 – September 1945) * [[North American P-51 Mustang]] (September 1945 – April 1951) * [[Gloster Meteor]] (April 1951 – August 1956) * [[CAC Sabre]] (November 1956 – July 1969) * [[Dassault Mirage III]] (July 1969 – June 1987) * [[Aermacchi MB-326|Macchi MB-326]] (January 1985 – June 1987) * [[McDonnell Douglas F/A-18 Hornet]] (June 1987 – current) * [[Pilatus PC-9]] (2000–03) ==See also== *[[McDonnell Douglas F/A-18 Hornet in Australian service]] ==Notes== {{reflist|30em}} 1946–1960|location=RAAF Williams, Victoria| publisher=[[RAAF Museum]] |url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/Publications/Details/237/Odd-Jobs---RAAF-Operations-in-Japan-The-Berlin-Airlift-Korea-Malaya-and-Malta-1946-1970.aspx|isbn=0-642-23482-5}} *{{cite Unwin]]|location=Crows Nest, New South Wales|isbn=978-1-74175-500-8}} *{{cite book|last=Johnston|first=Mark|authorlink=Mark Johnston (historian)|title=Whispering Death: Australian Airmen in the Pacific War|year=2011|publisher=Allen & Unwin|location=Crows Nest, New South Wales|isbn=978-1-74175-901-3}} *{{cite book|last=Krylov|first=Leonid |last2= Tepsurkaev|first2=Yuriy |title=Soviet MiG-15 Aces of the Korean War|location=Oxford|publisher=[[Osprey Publishing|Osprey]] |date= 2008 |isbn= 978-1-84603-299-8}} *{{cite book|last=Odgers | first=George |authorlink=George Odgers|origyear=1957|
